statement:
To the power series $$\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}a_k(x-x_0)^k$$ there exists a
number $r\in [0,\infty]$, its *radius of convergence*, such that the
series converges absolutely for all (real or complex) numbers $x$ with
$|x-x_0|<r$ and diverges whenever $|x-x_0|>r$. This is known as [*Abel’s
theorem on power series*]{}. (For $|x-x_0|= r$ no general statements can
be made.)

The radius of convergence is given by:
$$r=\liminf_{k\to\infty}\frac{1}{\sqrt[k]{|a_k|}}$$ and can also be
computed as $$r=\lim_{k\to\infty}\left|\frac{a_k}{a_{k+1}}\right|,$$ if
this limit exists.

It follows from the that for any radius $r'$ smaller than the radius of
convergence, the power series converges uniformly within the closed disk
of radius $r'$.
